channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Judge orders new limits on DOGE data access at Social Security Administration
item.description: A federal judge in Maryland granted a preliminary injunction that bars DOGE staffers from accessing non-anonymized personal data at the Social Security Administration.
item.content:encoded:
A federal judge in Maryland granted a preliminary injunction that bars DOGE staffers from accessing non-anonymized personal data at the Social Security Administration.

(Image credit: Kayla Bartkowski)
item.dc:creator: Stephen Fowler

item.title: FSU shooting leaves two dead. And, Trump criticizes Fed chairman over interest rates
item.description: A shooting on Florida State University's campus has left two people dead and six people injured. And, President Trump criticizes the Fed chairman for not cutting interest rates.
item.content:encoded:
A shooting on Florida State University's campus has left two people dead and six people injured. And, President Trump criticizes the Fed chairman for not cutting interest rates.

(Image credit: Tasos Katopodis)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: The NHL Stanley Cup Playoffs begin Saturday. Here's what to watch for
item.description: One top seed has never won a Stanley Cup. The other wasn't expected to make the playoffs at all. And a pair of brothers who burned bright for Team USA in February are set to return to the ice.
item.content:encoded:
One top seed has never won a Stanley Cup. The other wasn't expected to make the playoffs at all. And a pair of brothers who burned bright for Team USA in February are set to return to the ice.

(Image credit: Bruce Bennett)
item.dc:creator: Becky Sullivan

item.title: You're probably taking over-the-counter painkillers incorrectly
item.description: People often use the wrong painkiller or take too much too quickly, increasing the risk of side effects, say pharmacists. Here are safer and more effective ways to take drugs like Advil and Tylenol.
item.content:encoded:
People often use the wrong painkiller or take too much too quickly, increasing the risk of side effects, say pharmacists. Here are safer and more effective ways to take drugs like Advil and Tylenol.

(Image credit: Photo illustration by Beck Harlan/NPR)
item.dc:creator: Andee Tagle

item.title: 5 takeaways from the week: Nearing a constitutional crisis?
item.description: The week was dominated by news about the Maryland man illegally deported to El Salvador. But there was also concern over tariffs and Robert F. Kennedy's work as Health and Human Services secretary.
item.content:encoded:
The week was dominated by news about the Maryland man illegally deported to El Salvador. But there was also concern over tariffs and Robert F. Kennedy's work as Health and Human Services secretary.

(Image credit: Win McNamee)
item.dc:creator: Domenico Montanaro

item.title: The State Department is changing its mind about what it calls human rights
item.description: The agency's annual human rights reports are being purged of references to prison conditions, political corruption and other abuses.
item.content:encoded:
The agency's annual human rights reports are being purged of references to prison conditions, political corruption and other abuses.

(Image credit: Nicholas Kamm)
item.dc:creator: Graham Smith

item.title: A father remembers his only daughter, killed in the Oklahoma City bombing
item.description: In this edition of StoryCorps, a father remembers his daughter who was among 186 people killed when a federal office building in Oklahoma City was bombed 30 years ago.
item.content:encoded: In this edition of StoryCorps, a father remembers his daughter who was among 186 people killed when a federal office building in Oklahoma City was bombed 30 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Jud Esty-Kendall

item.title: Luigi Mangione indicted in federal court in CEO killing
item.description: Mangione was indicted on two counts of stalking, one firearms offense and murder through use of a firearm — a charge that could make him eligible for the death penalty.
item.content:encoded:
Mangione was indicted on two counts of stalking, one firearms offense and murder through use of a firearm — a charge that could make him eligible for the death penalty.

(Image credit: Spencer Platt)
item.dc:creator: Sarah Ventre

item.title: A wind project is stalled in New York. Experts worry about impacts across the U.S.
item.description: The Trump administration halted the construction of a New York offshore wind project. Legal analysts say it has implications far beyond the wind industry.
item.content:encoded:
The Trump administration halted the construction of a New York offshore wind project. Legal analysts say it has implications far beyond the wind industry.

(Image credit: Christopher Furlong)
item.dc:creator: Julia Simon

item.title: The CFPB starts to lay off staff as the agency plans a shift in its focus
item.description: A recent court ruling cleared the way for the firings, which follow a memo from the bureau's chief legal counsel outlining the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's new priorities.
item.content:encoded:
A recent court ruling cleared the way for the firings, which follow a memo from the bureau's chief legal counsel outlining the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's new priorities.

(Image credit: Alex Wong/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Laurel Wamsley
